Jewishness was suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1, WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN II, 137. On the theophoric element in this name, and the possibility of it being Jewish see Introduction 1.2.3. Many scholars (e.g. Tcherikover in CPJ 1, xix) identify the male Dositheus as almost uniquely Jewish and proceed to identify persons by this name as Jews. However, this is a circular argument, since it is unlikely that such a Greek name was used exclusively by Jews, see Introduction 1.2.3.1. absence of decoration and similarity to Jewish epitaphs of Leontopolis, see Introduction 6.5.1, but none of these are decisive.

This papyrus is dated to the fourth century (early Christian) and is replete with biblical names. Polyhistor, who wrote about her, lived in the early first century BCE.

This family manumitted a slave in the συναγωγῆ[ς]τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων (synagogue of the Jews), see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3, and Gibson, Jewish Manumission Inscriptions, 150-2.
The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 2.3.1.
In Greek – θ[ρ]επτὴν.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.

The manumission of this slave took place in a [προσ]ευχῆι (prayer house) usually understood as Jewish, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.1.1. The inscription, however, ends with the pagan formula ̔πο Δία Γῆν ̔́Ηλιον (through Zeus, Ge and Hlios), see Introduction 6.10.2. There is no need to assume this family was Jewish, see Gibson, Jewish Manumission Inscriptions, 108, and Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3.
The inscription is dated.
This is a Latin declension, see Introduction 2.3.3.7.1.
In Greek – Νεικομηδική.
This is the editor’s suggestion, because of some general impression. IJO 2 rejected this claim, see p. 325, n. 48.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

Jewishness was (not emphatically) suggested by the editor, based on the remarkable similarity of the inscription to CIJ728, which also record the murder of children and request revenge from God (there described as Θεὸν τὸν ̔́Υψιστουν τὸν Κύριου τῶν πνευμάτων καὶ πάσης σαρκὸς [Num 16:22]; here described as Κύρει Παντοκράτωρ – Lord the Almighty). On the similarity and non-Jewishness of Θεὸν τὸν ̔́Υψιστουνand Κύρει Παντοκράτωρ see Introduction 6.10.1.1. The main reason why this may be considered other than Jewish is the definitive date of this inscription 237/8 CE (just after the onset of Christianity), whereas the Delos inscriptions are dated on epigraphical grounds to the 2nd-1st centuries BCE.
The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 2.1. For the transliteration of χ with c see Introduction 2.3.2.2.2.
This curse tablet calls on the God Iau for help. This is typically Jewish, and no other deities or demigods are evoked. However, in “magical” texts one can never know, see Introduction 6.10.1.6.
For the transliteration of χ with c see Introduction 2.3.2.2.2.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3, but described on her tombstone as “proselyte,” see Introduction 6.1.6.2.
In Greek – τρεῖ[ς δεκ]άδος.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.
On the interchange of η and ι see Introduction 2.3.3.2.
The inscription was found on a Jewish ossuary from Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.5.7.

WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN II, 137. On the theophoric element in this name, and the possibility of it being Jewish see Introduction 1.2.3. Many scholars (e.g. Tcherikover in CPJ 1, xix) identify the male Dositheus as almost uniquely Jewish and proceed to identify persons by this name as Jews. However, this is a circular argument, since it is unlikely that such a Greek name was used exclusively by Jews, see Introduction 1.2.3.1.

Greek, WGE, 336. Eirene means peace. Scholars (e.g. Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 245) identify this name as a translation of the Hebrew שלום and interpret it as an exclusively Jewish name. But it is Greek and this assumption is thus unlikely, see Introduction 1.2.4.
